I generally don't write negative reviews unless something is truly amiss.

DISCLAIMER: THIS IS MORE OF A CONSUMER WARNING THAN A REVIEW.

One view of the forums or the recent reviews will tell you everything you need to know.
Vertigo Games has been abusing the Early Access Program to build a game on the backs of duped early adopters. What they promised years ago was to deliver a randomly generated, open world diving simulator with unparalleled realism, graphics, and gameplay.  What they have delivered over the past couple of years is a completely unstable, unplayable fantasy game with built-in monetization and in-game purchases, with small and broken maps.  Their screenshots DO NOT match the actual gameplay.  When the game used to work, it was a multiplayer gameplay clone of Depth Hunter 2: Deep Drive, a decent if barren clone.

Starting in November 2014, World of Diving has become the culmination of false promises of progress, game-breaking bugs, eye-splitting visual glitches, dysfunctional online servers (used for authentication and multiplayer), a failed and forced migration to Unity 5, and a game with a backward-moving progress bar...all which make for a very angry user community.  But alas, you can help!  They request additional cash donations on their website in return for future updates.

Early Access Review

*****Sharks will not attack you******
*****************************************
Update 10/30

The developers have added some much needed structure. There are now several types of challenges that renew each day as well as the addition of a metal detector that guides you to collectible coins which can be used to purchase various cosmetic additions like diving suites, watches, etc.

The daily challenges range from relaxing to frustrating. You’re told to take a picture of an object or group of fish and given some vague idea of where the thing is located. Some aren't timed which is nice, but the other side of that is the find a hidden object missions. In some cases I had to replay those missions over and over because I couldn't find a tea pot wedged in some obscure corner of the map (though you can kind of cheat if you know how).

The collectibles (which also include hidden pearls) and challenges give you a solid reason to explore every corner of each environment. There are even community missions and an editor to create your own.

So far this a great looking game that keeps getting better and better.

Original review below.
*****************************************
I pre-ordered this from their website so my play time has been almost entirely outside of steam. Would I reccommend this? Yes. It's a work of passion that deserves the following it needs to bring to all of its ideas to life. That being said I would like to offer a word of caution only so that people know that they're buying into now and don't potentially complain in the reviews.

In it's current state there isn't much to do beyond dive in the available areas and simply explore. Each area has a wreck that you can swim around (or inside) and each map is reasonable big, but that's about it. There is a daily mini game you can play where you have to find an object within a time limit, but the game basically tells you where it is so it will last 2 minutes max. You can clip directly through fish and plants, and you can't manually change your orientation. So no swimming upside down.

There are microtransactions, but they're purely cosmetic and don't at all lock off any meaningful content.

To sum it up: In its current state it's more a virtual museum than anything.

That aside the game looks great. It has full controller support and the multiplayer works really well. I personally find it both thrilling and tense to swim around the detailed enviroments and you can even tread on the surface. You can also take pictures of anything you like and save them to your hardrive.

This is a very cool game and a work of love, but very much Early Access. Given time I have no doubt it will be amazing!

P.S. Rift Supprt

Early Access Review

Introduction            	World of Diving is an amazingly beautiful and relaxing diving simulator. I found myself just wandering/swimming around the different levels just looking at the beautiful ocean life and ship wreaks. World of Diving is a great break from the usual fast-paced shooters, but it is not without faults. The in game “dive shop”, where you buy customizations, is filled with micro-transactions. Although you can unlock everything without buying it with real world money, the prices in the dive shop are very inflated. Along with the inflated prices, the updates are very slow coming. World of Diving also supports VR and player created content. (I’m waiting for steam workshop to be implemented) Even with the faults of this game, the multiplayer is a huge reason to buy this. It is tons of fun exploring the ocean with a few other friends.

Pros
Beautiful graphics
Several varied maps/locations
Easy and fun multiplayer
Tons of customizations
Beautiful and interactive ocean life
Plenty to do
Very relaxing
VR support




Cons
Requires secondary sign-in
Micro-transactions
Very slow movement
Slow updates
Repetitive “objectives”


Conclusion
World of Diving is a beautiful and relaxing diving simulator, but it is not without faults. There is a few issues with buying customizations and as well as the fact of the updates are taking forever to come out. Even with the few issues (will most likely be fixed before release) the multiplayer is a huge asset for World of Diving. If you are looking for a relaxing game to play by yourself or with friends this is for you. Don’t expect anything fast paced and exciting.

Early Access Review

World of Diving feels like something I *want* to like, but it's too inconsistent at this stage.  Graphically, it's quite beautiful.  The undersea world is rendered with appropriate murkiness; fish and dolphins flit about, sharks glide menacingly overhead, and shipwrecks look suitably weathered.

But that's about where it ends for me.  As nice as it looks, the ocean in World of Diving seems too static and artificial.  The fauna just swim about without much regard for the player.  The undersea wrecks are impressive, but non-interactive.  It looks real, but it doesn't feel real.

In fact, the only undersea interactivity is in the form of contrived challenges" or hunting for coins or pearls.  Those elements don't really fit with the more realistic presentation.  It's like the developers are attempting to shoehorn a game into a simulation.  The result ends up jarring; I was simultaneously immersed in a wondrous environment and yet constantly reminded that I am playing a video game.

My recommendation would be to allow an option to ditch the more obvious "game" like elements in favor of a more immersive experience with better interaction with the undersea world.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

World of Diving is quite simply the best looking dive simulation. With a strong community to match, this game will force the genre to step up its game to match.

World of Diving is currently in Alpha so my review may change. This game not only involves the simulation itself but also a vibrant online community and forum structure. The forums are filled with experienced real world divers, hardcore gamers, glitch finders, and people who simply wish they could dive in real life. But the one thing they all share is a desire to assist the developers Vertigo Games - create one of the best looking and best playing dive simulations on the market.

As far as the game itself - it already looks beautiful even without any sort of optimization. This facet can only get better with the addition of a day/night cycle and environmental effects. However, as a person who has grown up on the beaches in South Florida, I can tell you one thing... they have captured the lifestyle perfectly so far. Water effects like ripple and water light diffusion are spot on. And diving to a deep wreck already conjures up a feeling of excitement as you get closer and closer, and it finally comes into view.

Wrecks themselves have very early versions of their final textures - the last major update changed them dramatically from before. Yet they do have some weight to them - it feels like the objects have been underwater for some time.

Fish interaction is nearly nonexistent - however, there are flashes of greatness - Dolphins playing and following divers to a wreck - Fish scattering if a shark swims into their school - Some fish not being overly concerned about the presence of a diver and others seeking safer places if you even look at them wrong.

Overall, it is a promising alpha - and I encourage all fans of diving to join us in the World of Diving.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

World of Diving is a fun, neat game about, well, diving. There are various dive sites with plenty of vibrant wildlife and plants. The main focus of each area are shipwrecks. While fun to explore, the wrecks themselves feel small and don't take a while to explore. While being very fleshed out, the dive sites also feel a little small, but this is still early in development. For an early-access game, I came across very, very few bugs. The mission editor is also fun to tinker with and easily lets you fully realize amazing coral reefs. It was also clear to me that the developers are working very hard to improve the game with polls on loading screens allowing you to vote for what content should be added.

The core gameplay is simply diving. There are also missions which have you take certain pictures within an allotted amount of time. However, I didn't really come for the missions, they served as fun, little minigames that I did once in a while. The game is very set on experiencing things with a community, and in-game you could make all basic diving gestures.

The game does get a little boring sometimes, but I enjoy coming back every so often to explore and look for things that I've mixed. There are in-game currencies, doubloons, and paid-for currencies, pearls, that allow you to get certain gear and even diving buddies. However, these are purely cosmetic.

Overall, World of Diving is a fun, interesting game that I look forward to coming back to in the future. I can't wait to see how the game turns out from here and expect nothing but the best. This game has a lot of potential and Oculus Rift support makes the game a must-buy title for Rift users. Diving alone or with friends is a calming experience that is very refreshing coming off of the violence of most video games. This is a game for people who enjoy diving or nature, or are just looking for a cool, little sidegame with no real story elements that they can just pick-up and play without worrying about story elements or character progression.

SCORE: 7.5/10

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Since this game is still in developpment, it is not easy to give a review.

The project changes a lot and the dev team frequently add and remove features because of logistical or technical reason.

The community is very active on the forum and gives a lot of feedback, some of their members pressing the dev team to go forward faster than they can manage. The dev team tried to rush things because of that and the result was catastrophic. They came with a half finished adaptation of their game on the new game engine they worked on. Half demonstration, half game. It was a fail. Now they work on their own pace and build up the game again and the half game is becoming a whole game again, slowly.
Indeed this project will not be finished in 2015. They have a todo list untill may 2016 at least.

So : I strongnly advise NOT to buy this game now if you want a finished game. It is permanently changing and you will always be disappointed. The project is great and a lot of ideas already came through, but a lot didn't, some has been cancelled, or at least frozen. Other has been worked hard and are almost finished and results can already be seen.

Anyhow, buy this game in early access only if you have strong backbone and wishes to see a game in developpement with a lot of broken features. Wait for the final release if you wish a brand new polished game : the dev team showed they were able to create a fine working game... They could, so they still can.

But be honest with yourself before you buy it. This game is not expensive : $20 at the moment I am writing this review. You'll pay more for less, but you'll pay less for more too.


If you wish to spend a little time with people wishing to go forward : dive in. Water is hot and fishes are colorful.
If you wish to play a game of the same quality and professionalism than call of duty... Just walk out. It will never be that great. The dev team is a small dev team with humble capacities... But they have a strong resolution and no hidden agenda...

That's more than a lot of greenlight games but that's less than all AAA game.
This game is not Metal Gear. This game is not Mass Effect. This game is not Subnautica.

But this game is a project that will go through. There is no doubt about that.

Whether you will be amongst us or not is up to you.

I RECOMAND this game but not to everyone. If you don't have an experimental brain, forget it and come back next year.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

World of Diving is a first person underwater exploration game in which you explore the wonders of the ocean.  If you were expecting anything along the lines of Far Sky or an action-style type of game, then you will be dissappointed, as World of Diving is literally an underwater exploration game.  And it's pretty good for what it is.

World of Diving's gameplay is very limited.  You can explore the sea, explore the wrecks of ships, and take pictures.  It is very little to work with, but the game is a state of Early Access, and for the most part, these activities are actually more fun than they sound.  You can explore the sea for treasure to unlock new gear (which is only aesthetic), explore wrecks with a group of people, which is really fun since the wrecks are designed in a nice way, and picture taking is picture taking, though there are challenges, which are nice and spice up the gameplay.

In terms of movement, movement feels very fluid, and feels pretty realistic, it actually makes you feel like your swimming, and it's cool.

In terms of sounds, the game has a very ambient sound design, there isn't music, there are only the sounds of the ocean.  It's very immersive, though it would be cool to see an addition like an MP3 player.

In the graphics department, World of Diving shines.  Everything graphically is pretty beautiful, with the exception of some character animations and dolphin animations.  Besides that, the visuals lock in the feel of realism that the game creates so well in every department.  The  flashlight is also very good, the lighting visuals are superb.

Overall, it is obvious that the devs have a serious passion for what they are creating, and while it is a bit lackluster at the moment, it is still very fun.  If you have ever wanted to explore the ocean without getting wet, World of Diving is the best choice for that experience.

Thats a real shame as World Of Diving looks really good and is very promising.

VR is in it's infancy. There will be a set of Do's and Don'ts clearly defined one day.

I will re-visit this game once the VR movement has been improved.
